The first premise is a conditional statement of the form 'If P, then Q'. The second premise is an assertion that P is true. The conclusion is that Q is true. In this case, 'P' is 'The griffin was in the forest' and 'Q' is 'The unicorn was in the forest'. Since the argument follows the form of modus ponens, it is logically valid.
